content: The "Student Loan Fair Prepayment Act" allows for the application of prepayment amounts for FFEL and Direct Loans. Section 455(d) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to require the application of prepayment amounts for loans with different interest rates held by the same holder, prioritizing the outstanding balance of the loans. The Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to prioritize prepayment amounts for loans with different interest rates held by the same holder, focusing on the outstanding balance of the loans. Eligible borrowers are defined as those with no outstanding fees on any loan made under this part or part B. The borrower's outstanding balance of fees, collection costs, and late charges on loans under this part or part B are due to the holder, with exceptions for certain repayment plans. SEC. 3. APPLICATION OF PREPAYMENT AMOUNTS FOR PERKINS LOANS. Section 464(c)(1)(C) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to require institutions to use excess payments from borrowers with no outstanding balance to prepay the principal on the loan with the highest applicable rate. The amendment to Section 464(c)(1)(C) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 requires institutions to use excess payments from borrowers to prepay the principal on the loan with the highest applicable rate of interest, unless otherwise requested by the borrower in writing. Additionally, if a borrower has outstanding fees, the excess payment will first be applied towards those fees. SEC. 4. APPLICATION OF PREPAYMENT AMOUNTS FOR PRIVATE EDUCATION LOANS. Section 128(e) of the Truth in Lending Act is amended to require holders of multiple private education loans with different interest rates to apply prepayment amounts towards the loan with the highest interest rate first. The Truth in Lending Act now requires holders of multiple private education loans to apply prepayment amounts towards the loan with the highest interest rate first, with an exception for outstanding fees and charges on the loan. The Truth in Lending Act now mandates that prepayment amounts on multiple private education loans must be applied to the loan with the highest interest rate first, except for outstanding fees and charges.
